The game is good, but it takes up a lot of time. Time, specifically, which is not particularly engaging. A lot of it is gonna be spent flying around in space from one destination to the other, and it's gonna be especially aggravating whilst playing the story, which is going to be mostly nothing but flying to places (with a few interesting events), and will require you to get larger (and therefore slower) ships to progress in a meaningful way. You can start on the story initially, but I would highly suggest exploring the sandbox portion first until you've acquired funds and or better ships, or both, depending on how much of a pirate you arr.

In addition to this, save judiciously. This game has a few bugs, but the ones which are there can be catastrophic, and will cost you hours of flying around in space. Such bugs include but are not limited to: Certain questlines breaking for no reason, one of your ships crashing into you under the follow command, and autopilot deciding that your continued existence is not necessary to reach it's destination. You also cannot save on the fly unless you're in a station or have a stockpile of items called "salvage insurance", which makes it really hard to actually keep up to date saves unless you ping pong across stations.

There's a really large time investment here, unprecedented for a singleplayer game, not all of it is gonna be interactive. In a way, it's a bit like life. When you do get somewhere, it's very gratifying, but there are tons of risks along the way.

X3: Terran Conflict is a sprawling space simulation and trading game that stands out for its ambitious scale and intricate depth, offering a truly immersive experience for fans of open-ended sci-fi sandbox games. Developed by Egosoft, this title is part of the long-running X series, and it refines and expands upon the core mechanics that have defined the franchise for years. Released on Steam, X3: Terran Conflict invites players to lose themselves in a vast universe filled with dynamic economies, complex politics, and massive fleets, blending space combat, trading, and exploration in a way that few games can match.

At its heart, X3: Terran Conflict offers unparalleled freedom. Players begin with a single small ship and a basic understanding of the universe, but from there, the game opens up into a seemingly endless playground of possibilities. Whether you want to become a trader amassing wealth by buying and selling goods across star systems, a feared pirate commanding fleets and raiding convoys, or an empire builder constructing massive stations and managing resources, the game gives you the tools to carve your own path. This freedom is both exhilarating and daunting—the steep learning curve can be a barrier to entry, but the reward for patience is a richly detailed and reactive universe that responds meaningfully to your actions.

One of the standout features of X3: Terran Conflict is its incredibly detailed economic and faction systems. Each star system has its own economy, complete with factories producing goods, trading stations, and fluctuating supply and demand. Players can influence these economies by trading, investing, or even sabotaging competitors, making the universe feel alive and interconnected. Factions have their own agendas and relationships with one another, and your standing with each affects how they treat you. Aligning yourself with one faction can open doors to unique missions and technologies but may also invite hostility from rivals, adding layers of political intrigue to the gameplay.

Combat in X3: Terran Conflict is both tactical and satisfying. Ship-to-ship engagements range from small skirmishes to large-scale fleet battles, requiring players to manage shields, weapons, and positioning carefully. The variety of ship classes—from nimble fighters to massive capital ships—allows for diverse combat strategies, and the game rewards players who take the time to upgrade and customize their vessels. While combat can be challenging, especially against tougher enemies or in hostile territories, it rarely feels unfair. Instead, it encourages players to learn enemy patterns and optimize their loadouts, adding a layer of depth that complements the game’s strategic elements.

Visually, the game’s graphics may feel dated compared to more recent space sims, but the detailed ship models, colorful starfields, and varied station designs still convey a convincing and immersive sci-fi universe. The sound design, including an atmospheric soundtrack and dynamic combat noises, further enhances the experience, immersing players in the vastness of space. While the UI can feel cluttered and overwhelming at first, especially given the game’s complexity, it is functional and improves with familiarity, offering detailed information on everything from ship status to market conditions.

The storyline of X3: Terran Conflict is relatively light compared to the game’s sandbox elements but provides a solid framework that introduces players to the universe and its key factions, especially focusing on the Terran faction, humanity’s role in the galaxy, and their struggle to carve out a place among alien civilizations. The campaign missions are well-crafted and often challenging, serving as a useful guide to the game’s mechanics while also telling an engaging sci-fi tale. However, many players will likely spend most of their time in the open sandbox, creating their own stories and objectives.

One of the biggest challenges of X3: Terran Conflict is its learning curve. Newcomers may find the sheer volume of systems, controls, and economic intricacies intimidating. However, the game’s depth is also its greatest strength; for those willing to invest time, it offers one of the most rewarding and complex space simulations available. The community has also created numerous mods and quality-of-life improvements, which can help smooth the experience and add even more content, further extending the game’s lifespan.

In conclusion, X3: Terran Conflict is a monumental space simulation that delivers a rich, detailed, and expansive universe for players to explore, conquer, and influence. Its blend of trading, combat, and empire management, coupled with a dynamic economic system and faction politics, creates a living galaxy that feels both vast and responsive. While it demands patience and dedication to master, the depth and freedom it offers are unmatched in the genre. For players looking to immerse themselves in a complex, open-ended sci-fi sandbox with endless possibilities, X3: Terran Conflict remains a definitive and enduring choice.

Disciples II: Gallean’s Return is a comprehensive re-release of the acclaimed turn-based strategy game Disciples II: Dark Prophecy, bundled with its two expansion packs, Guardians of the Light and Servants of the Dark. Developed by Strategy First, this title represents one of the most distinct entries in the strategy genre, combining deep tactical combat with strong RPG elements and a dark, atmospheric fantasy setting. First released in the early 2000s, Gallean’s Return remains a compelling experience for players who enjoy deliberate pacing, persistent unit progression, and stylized art that still stands out today.

At the heart of the game is a traditional hex-grid strategy formula with a twist. Players control one of four distinct factions—the Empire, the Mountain Clans, the Legions of the Damned, or the Undead Hordes—each with its own units, storyline, and combat philosophy. Rather than controlling massive armies, players lead small, focused squads consisting of a hero and a handful of units that level up over time. This design choice makes each decision in battle matter immensely, as the loss of an experienced unit can be devastating and often unrecoverable. Unlike many turn-based strategy games that emphasize quantity and large-scale encounters, Disciples II rewards long-term planning, precise unit development, and careful positioning.

Each faction plays quite differently, not just in terms of unit design and aesthetics but also in how their tech trees, spells, and upgrade paths function. For example, the Empire is a balanced human faction with strong healing abilities and knights, while the Undead Hordes specialize in curses, debuffs, and resilient undead minions. The Mountain Clans focus on defense and earth-based magic, while the demonic Legions lean heavily into brute force and destruction. This asymmetry, coupled with detailed upgrade options, creates significant replay value and encourages players to explore the unique strengths of each race.

The structure of the game unfolds through long-form campaigns and custom scenarios. Campaign missions are narrative-driven and often include scripted events, branching objectives, and story developments that immerse the player in a dark, brooding world full of political intrigue, fallen gods, and doomed civilizations. The writing, while sometimes overwrought, carries a distinct tone that fits the game’s gothic art direction. The hand-drawn character portraits, ominous landscapes, and richly detailed unit animations contribute to a visual identity that remains iconic. Few strategy games of its era—or even today—look quite like Disciples II, with its blend of dark fantasy and painterly visual design.

Combat, while turn-based, is more rigid than some might expect. Units do not move on a battlefield grid during combat—instead, they remain in their formation, and turn order, attack type, and spell use determine the flow of battle. This simplified approach emphasizes preparation over improvisation. Knowing when to level up a unit into a support healer or a frontline damage dealer can decide the outcome of later battles. There is a deliberate rhythm to the game: exploration, city upgrading, hero training, and calculated skirmishes slowly build toward eventual map domination. It can feel slower than more action-oriented strategy titles, but it rewards patience and a methodical approach.

Another strength of Gallean’s Return lies in its strategic layer. Players control territory by capturing cities and mana nodes, which fuel spellcasting and research. Defending these points becomes critical as enemy factions grow stronger over time. The balance between offense and defense is tense and often forces hard decisions. Spells play a major role in turning the tide of battle or fortifying a position. Everything in the game, from hero abilities to resource collection, contributes to a tightly woven system that demands long-term thinking and risk assessment. Mistakes early on can snowball, which makes each campaign feel weighty and consequential.

Despite its many strengths, the game is not without flaws. The user interface feels clunky by modern standards, and the lack of quality-of-life features like auto-resolving battles or streamlined unit management can be frustrating. Pathfinding is occasionally awkward, and some campaign missions can feel overly punishing due to difficulty spikes or poorly telegraphed enemy movements. New players may also find the initial learning curve steep, as the game provides minimal hand-holding. However, these issues are often outweighed by the game’s charm, depth, and satisfying sense of progression.

Disciples II: Gallean’s Return stands as a classic in the genre—one that successfully blends turn-based tactical gameplay with rich lore and atmospheric world-building. It’s a game that values strategic foresight and unit loyalty over mindless conquest. For players willing to invest the time to master its systems, it offers a rewarding and memorable experience that holds up remarkably well despite its age. Its legacy as one of the most visually distinct and thoughtfully designed strategy titles of its era is well-earned, and for those seeking a dark, challenging, and narratively immersive tactical experience, Gallean’s Return remains a gem worth revisiting.

Brings me back to my childhood. This was one of first games i ever played and i like it.

It might be the nostalgia talking because I first played this when it was new, but there's a lot of little mechanics here that I don't see in newer games. Passing exp rewards to surviving party members rather than "You joined this fight with 4, so each unit gets 1/4 of the reward even though only 2 survived/stayed."
Movement over different terrain varies, so noting if a nearby enemy is flying or whatever and if you're next to trees can really make a difference.
The different factions work similarly enough to learn how to play with any of them, yet differ enough to easily have a preference. 
When advancing to another mission, you get to choose one leader and 5 items to take with you. Can be gear, potions, or treasure, so keeping something to sell for early gold on the next map is a valid tactic and you don't have to keep a warrior leader if you had more fun leveling up the mage. You could even leave them all behind if you feel like it. 
One of my favorite mechanics is transferring units between leaders. Use a scout to ensure that Dread Lord gets into the city to heal and replace it with a Fighter so you don't need to pay the huge revival cost and the party can keep going.

There's so many little things I love regardless that it's a 20+ year old game.

This game is beyond awesome. It has the bones to be the best space simulator ever made. 

There are automation elements where you can autopilot your ship to do practically anything you can manually do. You can do the same with ships you own, creating vast fleets of warships that can patrol sectors to eliminate enemies or destroy a specific factions trade routes. You can use the same automation to set up your own trading empire, with factories to produce basic goods like solar energy cells up to extremely elaborate super factories that create highly complex goods like weapons, ships, missiles, shields, and pretty much anything you could imagine. 

The factions are fun and interesting though the dialogue will get repetitive after a few dozen hours. Each faction controls their own territories and in Reunion they tend to go to war with racial enemies which can change the power dynamics in a sector at a moments notice. 

Ship to ship combat is fun up to a point. Flying your own ship is great, nothing is cooler than jumping into a system and chasing down a fat transport and lowering his shields until he ejects. You can either capture his goods, his ship, or the pilot himself. That is until your combat rating gets higher and the fights start getting unfair. You can be the best pilot in the universe in your M3 but when that capital ship or corvette shows up, you are pretty much guaranteed to lose. It will have dozens of support ships that will all simultaneously wreck your face. You can get creative with ship builds and last a good while, but eventually you will require fleets of your own ships to support you and thats where things fall apart.

The NPC AI is fantastic and believable. Your AI, however, is incredibly dumb. Ships in sectors you aren't present in are notorious for mysteriously exploding out of nowhere because they got too close to an enemy faction. Even ships in your own sector can fall prey to stupid decisions like coming through a gate the same time a capital ship is going into it and colliding. Trading ships can be incredibly dumb and will make a bee-line for the first enemy ship in a sector and get wasted. Entire stations can get destroyed because your support fleets break and don't patrol sectors correctly. There are lots of bugs in the AI on the player side. Patches and the like have come out to address some issues but if there is a major weakness in this game, your AI is it.

As for the rest of the game, its and absolute blast. I mostly played as a pirate and had the most fun I have ever had in a video game ambushing ships at gates to add to my collections. I even managed to capture a few capital ships and started my own shipyards up. That was until I invested most of my credits into a behemoth battleship that I couldn't possibly afford to arm. I had the lasers and the shields but it took an army of trading ships just to transport energy cells and missiles back and forth to it and the better equipped enemy AI's ate it for dinner.

Like I said at the beginning, this game has the bones to be the best spaceflight simulator ever made. It has everything. A graphical overhaul and some addressing of the AI would put this game a century ahead of it's time.

Graficznie ok, ale to kosmos, gry w kosmosie nawet sprzed 25 lat wyglądają nienagannie.
Widoki z kamer to także sp3rdolina. Widok z trzeciej osoby centralnie na tył statku, i na środku ekranu, tak, że zasłania celownik, którego zresztą nie ma w trzeciej osobie. Widok pierwszoosobowy, to dokładnie widok z czubka dziobu statku. Brak jakiejkolwiek kabiny, a przez to klimat sterowania statkiem zerowy.
Gra jest przeładowana opcjami i możliwościami a jednocześnie na powitanie nie daje jakiejkolwiek immersji przebywania w statku kosmicznym. Wygląda jakbyś latał kamerą po kosmosie i tyle.
Gdyby to byla jedyna gra w bibliotece, to pastwienie się nad nią i ogrywanie uparcie ma sens. Wygląda ładnie, udźwiękowiona jest ładnie, wszystko mogło by mieć klimat. Ale go nie ma. 
A i jeszcze inna irytująca rzecz. Serio gra X3 na swojej stronie sklepu ma filmiki reklamujące i porównujące z nowszą X4. Nawet devsi sami sugerują, by lepiej pominąć ten ich produkt? Dobre.

Цена у производителя больше, чем предлагает потребитель, бывает в два-три раза. Три производства в одной систем( явный переизбыток) ставят цену выше, чем в системах без такого производства. Шикарная экономическая модель. Так можно долго и упорно бороздить просторы вселенной, при этом совершенно напрасно. Во второй такая же тема была. Первая часть намного вменяемая и логичная.
Complex, odd, and totally wonderful.
Undurchsichtig aber gut.
